race.name: Waukon 100
race.tagline: 100 miles through Iowa's Driftless region with 5,000 feet of climbing and river valley gravel.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Iowa countryside. Significant elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Iowa event. Rolling terrain with remote access, moderate costs, 100-mile distance, significant elevation, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Waukon 100 is a local event in Iowa—rolling terrain with significant elevation over 100 miles. The Iowa countryside is nice and the distance/elevation are challenging, but the small local field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Iowa century gravel race. Worth it for Iowa/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Iowa—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Iowa races: Gravel Worlds, RAGBRAI.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Waukon has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Waukon has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

course_description.signature_challenge: Iowa rolling terrain over 100 miles with significant elevation.

non_negotiables.why: 100-mile distance with significant elevation requires sustained effort.
Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Local event with 100-mile rolling terrain and significant elevation.

logistics.explanation: Church basement packet pickup and 6:00AM race day check-in covers the basics without sophistication. The sweep ending at 2:00PM creates a hard cutoff that could strand unprepared riders miles from anywhere in rural Waukon.

length.explanation: 100 miles with 5000 feet of climbing hits the century distance sweet spot for serious gravel challenge. The route explores the driftless region's "long valleys and steep ridges" north of Waukon, delivering substantial distance with meaningful terrain variety. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: The driftless region creates "an amazing series of long valleys and steep ridges" that challenge Iowa's flat reputation. As one competitive rider noted, "Make no mistake, there's a bit more climbing in Waukon than the Silver City race, but it's absolutely worth it." Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: 4,300 feet over 100k delivers climbing for the Midwest, described as 'a bit more climbing' than comparable series races. That's 70 feet per mile average, which creates real fatigue without requiring mountain bike gearing. For Iowa standards, this represents serious vertical — elsewhere, it's a warm-up. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: June 21st in Iowa brings heat and humidity with zero weather mitigation mentioned in race planning. The 7:00AM start helps beat heat, but Iowa summer weather can turn ugly fast with no documented contingency plans. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: This is Iowa with zero altitude considerations for performance or acclimatization. The only elevation that matters is the 5000 feet you'll climb during the race through the Upper Iowa River bottoms and surrounding ridges. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The route explores "all the beauty of the Upper Iowa River and Waterloo river bottoms" through terrain that organizers admit "might surprise you." The driftless region offers Iowa's most varied topography, though adventure here means discovering regional gems rather than conquering legendary terrain.

prestige.explanation: Elite winner Mitch Brekke was featured on the Iowa Gravel Series Podium Podcast for "his unbelievable journey," but competitive depth remains regional. The race explicitly positions itself as "friendly to both new and experienced racers" rather than pursuing elite field development.

race_quality.explanation: The race includes "chip timing, marked course, pro photography and aid stations" with tiered registration packages. Organizers emphasize that riders can "know the route will be well marked and the people friendly," prioritizing execution basics over premium production value.

experience.explanation: Packet pickup at St. John the Baptist Church epitomizes small-town gravel racing. Ian Frink discussed "his experiences in the Waukon 100, and his thoughts on the gravel racing community" in podcast coverage, suggesting meaningful rider engagement despite humble production scale.

community.explanation: The Iowa Gravel Series philosophy focuses on "having a great day in the saddle and riding some of the best roads in Iowa" rather than pure competition. The race welcomes riders you can "invite your family or buddy to that's new to gravel grinding," creating inclusive rather than intimidating atmosphere.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 50-100 riders, no field size data available, with competitive depth limited to regional weekend warriors. While Mitch Brekke's elite victory generated podcast coverage, the emphasis on being "friendly to new racers" confirms this attracts participation over serious competition. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: The race delivers 100 miles through Iowa's most varied terrain with "chip timing, marked course, pro photography and aid stations." Tiered registration options including lunch and shirt packages suggest reasonable pricing for the distance and support provided in the driftless region.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $75-100. Waukon, Iowa keeps costs reasonable without premium pricing pressure from prestige or demand. The race date coordination with packet pickup the night before suggests local lodging exists and remains accessible for Midwest gravel racing budgets. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel M
primary.why: Mixed-terrain specialist. Balanced grip and speed for variable conditions.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Silver City and Waukon 100 Podiums!
videos.description:
So many links in the description! ⬇️
This is the first of possibly more podcast discussions we're going to try out. The Iowa Gravel Series Podium Podcast is an opportunity for us to sit down with the those standing on the podium at our races, learn a bit about them and their methods when it comes to gravel racing.

In this first episode we have racers from the 2021 Glenwood Gravel, 2022 Silver City Century, and 2022 Waukon 100.

Big shout out to our sponsors:
BikeRags: https://bikeragsapparel.com/
XX2i: https://www.xx2i.com/
&Collar: https://andcollar.com/

Here are the racers we're talking to today:
Jonathan Wait: https://www.strava.com/athletes/925353
Kari Ann Pappas
Travis Loewens: https://www.strava.com/athletes/356232

Derek Henscheid: https://www.strava.com/athletes/5973826
Phil Sime: https://www.strava.com/athletes/5959547

videos.title: Ian Frink
videos.description: We're still playing catch-up from the 2024 season. We're starting out with Ian, who raced in the 2024 Waukon 100 50km, where he secured an impressive third-place finish. In this conversation, we delve into Ian's journey into gravel racing, his experiences in the Waukon 100, and his thoughts on the gravel racing community. Ian is a down to earth guy and it was a pleasure chatting with him and getting to know him a little bit better. We chat about the usual mental and physical aspects of gravel racing, the importance of sportsmanship, and the beauty of Iowa gravel.

videos.curation_reason: Recent first-person interview with a 2024 Waukon 100 podium finisher discussing his race experience.

quotes.text: The good news and bad news is that the worst gravel on the route is on this first straightaway - it's not terrible, it's not dangerous, it's just a little bit looser. We got some big trucks that like to drive on it so until you hit the turn it's just not the greatest gravel but it's the worst that you'll see on the whole route.

It's absolutely one of my favorite courses, it's a beautiful area so lucky to be out in Allamakee county and to enjoy this beautiful land. It really is a special part of Iowa - you'll notice some trout streams and you'll probably even dodge some fishermen out on an early morning fishing expedition.
